title: Opening Bell: Dollar, Yields Drop on Renewed Sino-U.S. Tension; Futures Slip
text:
China warned it would take 'strong measures' after U.S. Congressional lawmakers expressed support for Hong Kong protestors

Yesterday, U.S. stocks climbed to four-week high on earnings optimism, with the S&P 500 topping 3,000 intraday

Gold falls despite U.S. asset risk-off

Key Events

With tensions increasing between the U.S. and China over in Hong Kong, U.S. futures contracts are slumping. Asian stocks ignored geopolitics during this morning's trade and instead followed yesterday’s U.S. session higher, focusing on optimism regarding corporate earnings results and a potential Brexit deal.

Contracts on the , and have recouped some of their losses, but remain lower nonetheless. The unease ahead of the U.S. open comes after China threatened countermeasures in response to a U.S. House bill supporting Hong Kong protestors.

Global Financial Affairs

European futures were flat today, as if traders were clinging to a middle ground, unable to decide between the rallies in Asia or the losses in U.S. futures.

Except for China’s (-0.4%), all Asia-Pacific benchmarks were in the green. , (+1.27%), beat regional indices. South Korea's advanced 0.71%, maintaining gains after the country's central bank for the second time in three months, matching a record low in order to combat increasing deflationary pressures.

During yesterday’s U.S. session, stocks hit a four weak high on earnings beats. and shares tracked the broader equity activity. The jumped more than 1.2%, while the topped 3,000 on an intraday basis for the first time in three weeks.

U.S. yields, including for the Treasury note, dropped along with global rates, as Brexit deal optimism increased.

UST 10-Y Daily

Technically, yields met with resistance at the top of a symmetrical triangle—a pattern illustrating a stand-off between Treasury buyers and sellers—and the 100 DMA. The triangle’s development below the downtrend line since November 2018 gives Treasury bulls an edge, suggesting yields will break to the downside of the triangle.

DXY Daily

On an intraday basis, the has broken the bottom side of a rising channel, falling to its lowest point since August.

GBPUSD Daily

maintained gains after surging yesterday, as the UK and EU appear to be come to the brink of a Brexit deal

Gold Daily

Despite lower U.S. futures, falling yields and a sagging dollar, has edged lower earlier today. Technically, the yellow metal has been trading within a falling channel since early September.

BTC/USD Daily

's slump continues. For added bearish emphasis it slipped below its rising channel whose upper boundary is also the cryptocurrency's 200 DMA. However, because of the digital currency’s volatile nature, we’re not calling a downside breakout yet. That would occur when a full, long red candle develops on its downside.

Up Ahead

U.S. , released today, are forecast to increase for a seventh straight month.

China releases third-quarter , September and data on Friday.

Market Moves

Stocks

Japan’s rose 0.7%, after climbing as much as 1.6% earlier.

Australia’s gained almost 1.3%.

Korea’s KOSPI rose 0.71%.

Hong Kong's was up 0.61%.

Currencies

The Dollar Index rebounded to 98.25 from 98.17, paring a decline to less than 0.05%.

The rose 0.2% to 108.68 per dollar.

The fell 0.3% to 7.1036 per dollar.

The traded at $1.1036, little changed.

The was at $1.2768, down 0.1% after jumping 1.4% overnight.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasuries fell three basis points to 1.74%.

Australia’s bond yield rose four basis points to 1.05%.

Commodities

Gold edged lower to at $1,481.13.
